sentence: Sunday evening everyone, except Pim and me, was clustered around the radio, listening to the “Immortal Music of the German Masters.” Dussel kept twisting and turning the knobs, which annoyed Peter, and the others too.

The reason for the disagreement wasn’t particularly interesting in and of itself, but Peter has apparently taken the matter very much to heart, because this morning, when I was rummaging around in the crate of books in the attic, Peter came up and began telling me what had happened.
Dussel replied in his haughtiest tone, “Ich mach’ das schon!”* Peter got angry and made an insolent remark.
However, since I wanted him to go on talking quietly about himself, I hid my laughter, sat down on a cushion on the floor, wrapped my arms around my knees and gazed at him intently.
I start stuttering and blushing and I twist my words around so much I finally have to stop, because I can’t find the right words.
All day long I tried not to look at him too much, because whenever I did, I caught him looking at me and then—well, it made me feel wonderful inside, and that’s not a feeling I should have too often.
After restraining himself for half an hour, Peter asked somewhat irritably if he would stop fiddling with the radio.
